From Simply Wall Street, 1/24/2019 -- Over the last three years ALOT has shrunk its earnings per share by an average of 4.0% per year. Declining earnings per share suggest that the business performance wouldn’t really justify a high pay packet for the CEO, who joined the company in 2014. Thus, we can conclude that Greg Woods receives more in total compensation than the median of a group of companies in the same market, and of similar size.

Wow, this is really a disturbing report, with revenues declining 6% bringing the bottom line down as well by around 8%. Where is the growth, especially since the 2nd quarter ended with a big, strong backlog? No company can continue to cut costs to achieve greater profitability, effectively reducing the size of the enterprise. Rising revenue is key to growth, and even with more sales offices, sales continue to decline, flat at best. Yet management speaks as if this is a good report! Any other company's stock price would take a 40% haircut with a report like this. The color printer division has eliminated 3 product lines and replaced them with one, which can't be a winning formula. Gone are the Vivo, Zeo and Pronto printers, each which represented different markets and applications. One sole new printer has been added to offset the loss, representing lost market coverage.
Way to go Woody, down 20% to 16 in one fowl swoop! Hideous earnings report, you need to focus on getting some bar code printer contracts, like Zebra did. They rose to well over 100 many years ago.

Today's announced "Everest Chart Recorder" is a re-launch of an existing product, which I believe was called the EV-2. Now it's the EV-5000. Way to knock out exciting new products! The "Everest Chart Recorder" was spawned from the original Everest system, which was released around 25 yrs ago. It was great in the 90s, but is now getting long in the tooth.

The original company name Astro-Med from the 1970s had to do with cardiology products, cath lab data recorders, not the neurological Grass products. Grass wan not purchased until the late 1990s, and the cath lab business was already finished. The flagship cardiology recorder was called the K3, and they never gained any traction and sold it to a Texas firm for pennies on the dollar. The Grass name and it's ultimate divestiture to Natus was unrelated to the "Med" in the company name. Woody's explanation of that new name was way off base and he completely missed the target, that they were no longer medically related because of the divestiture of Grass. The founder always had the desire to get further integrated with the medical field, but the Cath Lab recorders were the limit, and those were marketed only into the mid 1990s, before the purchase of Grass Instruments and Telefactor Corp.

Come on Woody, the last two quarters have been awful, long before the coronavirus even surfaced. Do the right thing...And where is the buy-back program during this time of deflated share prices???? It is approved by the Board, hit the market and buy some share for the treasury at these low prices.

I wonder how Yvonne Schlaeppi, the newly appointed director is working out. She's replaced either retiring Machletchie or Everett V. Pizzuti, who's doing the same. Pizzuti does not often get deserved credit for having been a co-founder of the co. along with the late Albert W. Ondis back in the late 60s. Cheers to them and good luck to Everett!! New management gives little credit to the people who got the whole ball rolling, conceptually and in practice. They brought it to it's current state of two divisions, one for label printers and one for T&M that includes the cockpit printer business. The founders left the co. primed for expansion with everything established and awaiting additional incentives.

The QuickLabel tagline is backward, it should be, "The Labels You Need, When you Want Them, Not "the labels you want, when you need them". I'm surprised nobody ever flipped that around years ago.

Following the dismal 2Q financial report, this POS looks to be weakening to the price range in the 12s. For years it has continued to fall short of projected sales and earnings. Even after several acquisitions, revenue is only slightly higher than before the multi-million dollar acquired companies. Label and printer companies galore, even the latest in Europe, but sales still fall in the mid $20M range every quarter; should have vaulted into the mid-$30m range quarterly by now. Sell 'em if you got 'em.
